Tildon:'massive separation of individuals'
By MICHAEL MANES
Dr. Tyson Tildon, associate
professor of pediatrics at the
University of Maryland, and
author of The Angle-Saxon
Agony, was the guest lecturer of
this week's Sunday Experience
program.
Tildon's lecture dealt with
what he considered to be
America's greatest problem, the
pain of alienation between
people in society.
"There is a massive separation
of individuals," which Tildon
referred to as "the psychic
distance between people."
Tildon stated people have
become alienated from each
other and have been forced to
lose part of reality. This, he
asserted, has stifled our inherent
feelings, which are cooperative,
not competitive, with our fellow
mankind. As a result, "we are so
used to lying and being
hypocritical that every time we
look towards an experience we
distort things."
Taking the position of an
historian, Tildon blamed
alienation on mankind's thirst to
control the environment and
forces of society to provide for

his comforts. Thus, Tildon
divided societies into two camps,
those which depend on control
and those which exist on
cooperation. Because Tildon
believes that man, especially
American, will inevitably
progress from a society of
control to one of cooperation, he
referred to our present society of
control as the "Old Regime."
"This is the reason I am
against Black Panthers, Women's
Lib, and Nixon," Tildon asserted,
"because these groups seek to
control, and not cooperate."
Tildon explained that in his
opinion Jesus was the last
revolutionist because Jesus'
revolution was philosophical in
nature and not political, being
one of freedom and peace.
Tildon went on to explain the
mechanism of the "control
philosophy" by stating that
control has caused us to separate
our thought from our fears, our
reason from our passion. Tildon
believes that when man divided
his thoughts from his fears, he
also divided his senses. Therefore,
men relate to each other only
through sight and sound,
keeping his sense of smell, taste

and touch to himself.
"Although the sense of hearing
and seeing are good from the
physical world," Tildon
explained, "I do not think we are
just a biochemical bag walking
around."
Dehumanized.
To illustrate his argument,
Tildon pointed out instances in
life which have become
dehumanized.
'Even the ever/day
expression, 'It's nothing

personal', is dehumanizing
because of the inability of man
to subjectively relate to man."
"Being human," Tildon
concluded, "is to allow for a
better process to experience
life."
Although the audience was
receptive to Tildon's statement
and conclusions, they did
question certain ambiguities and
many times the Socratic method
was used to definitively state
certain points.

Tildon:'massive separation of individuals'
By MICHAEL MANES
Dr. Tyson Tildon, associate
professor of pediatrics at the
University of Maryland, and
author of The Angle-Saxon
Agony, was the guest lecturer of
this week's Sunday Experience
program.
Tildon's lecture dealt with
what he considered to be
America's greatest problem, the
pain of alienation between
people in society.
"There is a massive separation
of individuals," which Tildon
referred to as "the psychic
distance between people."
Tildon stated people have
become alienated from each
other and have been forced to
lose part of reality. This, he
asserted, has stifled our inherent
feelings, which are cooperative,
not competitive, with our fellow
mankind. As a result, "we are so
used to lying and being
hypocritical that every time we
look towards an experience we
distort things."
Taking the position of an
historian, Tildon blamed
alienation on mankind's thirst to
control the environment and
forces of society to provide for

his comforts. Thus, Tildon
divided societies into two camps,
those which depend on control
and those which exist on
cooperation. Because Tildon
believes that man, especially
American, will inevitably
progress from a society of
control to one of cooperation, he
referred to our present society of
control as the "Old Regime."
"This is the reason I am
against Black Panthers, Women's
Lib, and Nixon," Tildon asserted,
"because these groups seek to
control, and not cooperate."
Tildon explained that in his
opinion Jesus was the last
revolutionist because Jesus'
revolution was philosophical in
nature and not political, being
one of freedom and peace.
Tildon went on to explain the
mechanism of the "control
philosophy" by stating that
control has caused us to separate
our thought from our fears, our
reason from our passion. Tildon
believes that when man divided
his thoughts from his fears, he
also divided his senses. Therefore,
men relate to each other only
through sight and sound,
keeping his sense of smell, taste

and touch to himself.
"Although the sense of hearing
and seeing are good from the
physical world," Tildon
explained, "I do not think we are
just a biochemical bag walking
around."
Dehumanized.
To illustrate his argument,
Tildon pointed out instances in
life which have become
dehumanized.
'Even the ever/day
expression, 'It's nothing

personal', is dehumanizing
because of the inability of man
to subjectively relate to man."
"Being human," Tildon
concluded, "is to allow for a
better process to experience
life."
Although the audience was
receptive to Tildon's statement
and conclusions, they did
question certain ambiguities and
many times the Socratic method
was used to definitively state
certain points.
